request_pathways.name: Form 1989: Consent to Release of Information and Right of Access Request
Mail to HIM Department, 200 Hawkins Dr., HSSB Ste. 100, Iowa City, IA 52242

forms.document_type: ROI authorization and patient access request form

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patient downloads a dual-purpose PDF form (Consent to Release and Right of Access Request), prints and completes it by hand, then submits via email, fax, or mail.

red_flags: Current form (2024) regressed from 50 fillable fields to zero, making it less digitally accessible than the older version
Current form removed 'Myself at the address above' recipient option that was present in the older version
bright_spots: Form title explicitly names 'Right of Access Request' alongside release authorization
Email submission accepted (him-consentform@uiowa.edu) — above average for ROI form submission
Legacy entity lines accommodate patients from merged organizations (Corridor OB GYN, Mercy Clinics, Mercy Hospital)
Five delivery format options including electronic media (CD, USB, email)

findability.rationale: Level 5: Prominently available with minimal effort — a single web search returns the direct PDF link, and the institutional medical records page provides clear context and instructions.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 3: Usable digitally with workarounds — the form has zero fillable fields requiring print-and-handwrite, but fax and email submission are available; a patient could use third-party PDF annotation tools as a workaround.

content_design.rationale: Level 4: Well-organized single-page form with logical flow and comprehensive record type options, but lacks section headers and has moderately dense consent language.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can use the process but it wasn't designed for them — the form title acknowledges right of access but the workflow treats patient self-access identically to third-party release with no 'send to myself' shortcut.

compliance.rationale: Level 4: Minor ambiguities but nothing materially impeding — 30-day response time stated, no notarization required, non-conditioning statement present, but fee language is vague and doesn't distinguish patient access fees from third-party fees.

overall.summary: UIHC provides an easily findable, concise dual-purpose form with flexible submission options, but the lack of fillable fields and absence of a differentiated patient self-access pathway prevent a higher rating.
